metadata.case_name: Appellant (Railway Clerk) v. Union of India

facts.text: Appellant was a clerk in the service of the East Indian Railways.
Appellant was compulsorily retired from service with effect from June 30, 1948, on attaining the age of 55 years.
Appellant's prayer for further retention in service under Rule 2046/2 of the Railway Establishment Code was rejected.

Appellant filed suit in the court of the Civil Judge, Lucknow, seeking declaratory decree that the order of compulsory retirement was illegal and void, and money decree for arrears of pay assuming continuance in service.
Main defence by respondent (Union of India) was denial of appellant's right to be retained in service under the rules.
Trial Court accepted plaintiff's contention, granted declaration as prayed and decreed claim for money in part.

Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench, in First Civil Appeal No. 3 of 1956, by judgment dated November 20, 1958, allowed the appeal, held Rule 2046 gave no right to continue beyond 55, and dismissed the suit.
Present appeal to Supreme Court on certificate granted by High Court under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.
Appellant's case that he continued to be efficient even after attaining age of 55 years not disputed by respondent.
Government of India decision on September 8, 1948, that non-ministerial servant under FR 56(b)(i) aged 55-60 should not be retired without reasonable opportunity to show cause.

Ministry of Railways notification dated October 19, 1948, for dealing with retirement of ministerial servants under Rule 2046(2)(a), corresponding to Government decision, but no action for already retired.
Railway Board notification dated April 15, 1952, that ministerial servants retired after September 8, 1948, but before 60 without complying with Art. 311(2) to be taken back under certain conditions.

legal_issues.text: Whether on proper interpretation of Rule 2046/2(a) of Railway Establishment Code (identical to FR 56(b)(i)), the appellant had right to be retained in service till age of 60 years if he continued efficient.

Whether notifications dated October 19, 1948 and April 15, 1952 giving special treatment to ministerial servants retired under Rule 2046(2)(a) after September 8, 1948 are discriminatory under Art. 14.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant entitled to be retained under Rule 2046/2 till age 60 if continued efficient; order of compulsory retirement at 55 void.
Use of 'but should ordinarily be retained in service if he continues to be efficient up to the age of 60 years' cuts down right to retire at 55, creating right to retention if efficient.
Notifications of 1948 and 1952 discriminatory by denying same advantage to appellant retired before September 8, 1948.

respondent_arguments.text: Denial of right to be retained in service under Rule 2046/2 beyond age 55.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 2046/2(a) allows authority to require retirement at 55; 'but should ordinarily be retained if efficient up to 60' gives option to retain, not a right; 'ordinarily' means in majority cases but not invariably; authority has discretion considering other circumstances.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No right in servant to be retained even if efficient; interpretation adopted by several High Courts.

court_reasoning.text: Jai Ram v. Union of India observation was assumptive for argument, not decision on rule's meaning.
Classification of retired before/after September 8, 1948 reasonable; no arbitrariness in not applying new procedure retrospectively.

holdings.text: Railway ministerial servant under Rule 2046/2(a) may be compulsorily retired at 55; authority has option but no obligation to retain till 60 even if efficient.
Notifications creating classes based on retirement date before/after September 8, 1948 reasonable and not violative of Art. 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jai Ram v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Observation on rule was obiter assumptive, not binding interpretation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Basant Kumar Pal v. The Chief Electrical Engineer
precedents_cited.relevance: Adopted interpretation that no right to continue beyond 55.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kishan Dayal v. General Manager, Northern Railway
precedents_cited.relevance: Adopted interpretation that no right to continue beyond 55.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raghunath Narain Mathur v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Adopted interpretation that no right to continue beyond 55.

statutes_cited.name: Railway Establishment Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs retirement of railway servants; interpreted as giving discretion, not right, to retain ministerial servants under cl.(a) beyond 55 if efficient.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.14: No discrimination in notifications; Art.133: Certificate for appeal; Art.311: Compliance in later retirements.

statutes_cited.name: Fundamental Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Identical to Rule 2046/2(a); governs similar retirements.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court correct in holding no right under Rule 2046/2(a) to continue beyond 55; no discrimination under Art.14.
outcome.costs: No order as to costs, as appellant is a pauper.

key_quotes.text: "A ministerial servant who is not governed by sub-cl. (b) may be required to retire at the age of 55 years but should ordinarily be retained in service if he continues to be efficient up to the age of 60 years."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Exact words of Rule 2046/2(a) central to interpretation.

key_quotes.text: "Ordinarily means in the large majority of cases but not invariably. This itself emphasises the fact that the appropriate authority is not bound to retain the servant after he attains the age of 55 even if he continues to be efficient."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to holding that no absolute right to retention.

key_quotes.text: "We therefore hold that the High Court was right in holding that this rule gave the plaintiff no right to continue in service beyond the age of 55."
key_quotes.speaker: court
